text: [Music]
thank you ge is undergoing one of the
largest and frankly most important
transformations in our 140e history
we've moved to starting to combine the
physical world of machines with the
logical world and the digital world of
software to create new outcomes for our
customers they're going to change the
way they operate their businesses for
example in our renewal M's business
where we make wind turbines we're
creating a software enabled or a softwar
defined wind farm this wind farm allows
the turbines to individually talk to
each other so they can understand how
each is operating to understand the
ambient temperature wind and weather
that is local to that environment and
optimize themselves and that softwar
defined wind turbine environment is
seeing 10 to 20% improvements in power
output through the combination of the
physical in the digital world inside GE
we're also on the same journey in our
manufacturing plant in Greenville South
Carolina we're taking the machine data
the information around how the plant
operates and we're combining it with the
engineering data around how parts are
designed we're designing a solution that
will allow us to reduce the cycle time
of new part introduction by 20% by
connecting the 3D model that comes off
an engineer's desktop and with no manual
touch being be able to produce that on
the manufacturing line and be able to
reduce the overall cost of operations
and the cost to our customers this will
generate a billion dollars of
productivity across the general electric
company over the next five
years today Industrials have to become
digital to thrive going
forward the reality is that when
customers and when companies start to
understand that they can take their
domain expertise so within GE it's our
140 years of experience in creating
power it's our understanding of aircraft
engines it's our understanding of the
locomotive market and combine that with
new digital tools they're able to create
outcomes that they were never able to
create before in fact GE strives to be a
worldclass leading digital Industrial
company for the future and we will
generate by the year 2020 $15 billion of
our revenue from software that will make
us one of the top 10 software companies
in the
world now as you can imagine for a
company that is 140 years old we've got
a lot of sins of the past to deal with
like many of you I've got 9,000
applications that we use across our
business today we've got over 300 erps
two years ago that were running our
business and too many physical data
centers to talk about and so we've
really had to look at what we were going
to have to change within our own
environment to enable us to become this
leading digital Industrial in the world
and it started with some simple things
going from bespoke Standalone systems
that didn't talk to one another to a
real service management view for how we
provide services and how we provide
transactions to our environment to
rethink the network 2,000 locations
around the world that are network
connected we need to think about the
network very differently connections
aren't going to look like physical
locations anymore they're going to be
mobile we're talking to aircraft that
are flying around the world we're
talking to power plants that are in the
middle of deserts so we had to rethink
the way we think about Network
segmentation we had to take more of a
risk-based approach to security and
controls we're dealing with some of the

understanding the security and
understanding how to take a risk-based

self-service and automation had to be
the Mantra with everything that we do
and at the end of the day financial
transparency for our end use users was a
critical component of how we were going
to deliver going forward and there were
three basic things that we fundamentally
had to change to be able to get this
right the first is
people uh like many of you over the last
10 years we outsourced way too much and
so part of it was retooling our own
environment in the last two years we've
HED over 2,000 it professionals bringing
our knowledge Capital back into GE and
we've made a$1 billion investment in
creating a software center of excellence
and Design Center in San Ramone
California that will enable us to build
build high quality applications and
Technology now the second element that
we had to get right was technology we're
taking a build versus buy mentality for
things that matter Andy in the keynote
at the beginning brought up be
differentiated on things that matter and
things that that aren't um and for us
what differentiates us is the software
and algorithms that allow us and our
customers to run their businesses
differently the things that we're going
to choose to buy are the things that
don't differ differentiate us and for
those we're going to have great partners
and that's frankly where AWS comes to

the past four years and has become one
of our trusted Partners why because I'm
not going to sell another aircraft
engine because I run a global compute
Factory very well I'm not going to sell

aws's differenti differentiator in the

that's what we feel they do Best in
Class and that's what's made them a

forward um so for us the what this looks
like going forward we're going to
migrate over 9,000 workloads into AWS
over the next three years we're going to
go from having over 9,000 applications
to 4,000 applications in our environment
we're going to go from 34 dat data
centers to four data centers and those
four data centers will only hold what we
value most secretly our secret sauce on
things that differentiate us completely
in the environment everything else is
going to go to AWS from our perspective
going forward AWS is our trusted partner
that's going to run our company for the
next 140 years but you know an example
speaks louder than words and so I
thought I would just share with you one
really simple example that I think
everybody will get and it comes from our
oil and gas business they've migrated
over 50% of their load already in AWS
and one of the applications they've
moved is a configurator this is a
quoting tool that our uh sales teams use
Mobile in the work in the in the
customer sites to be able to quote for
products uh in the old world we would
spend about $62,000 to run this
application we would take in about
$600,000 in orders and anytime that we
wanted to push a change into this
environment it would take us on average
20 days to move into that
environment after moving to AWS that
same application now runs for
$6,000 we're able to deploy code in less
than 2 minutes instead of 20 days and at
the end of the day we had a ton of
unintended consequences that that were
on the good side Global performance went
up of availability of the application
went up the the sales team looked at
this as a differentiator for them and
being able to quote more tools because
the application actually worked better
in their environment so the unintended
consequences for us are almost better
than the intended consequences of our
move to the to the cloud so going
forward this is where we're going we
intend to move over 60% of our Global
workload into AWS for us this is no
longer an experiment it's no longer a
test it's no longer something that we
talk about being probable it's

much
